topic.title: Some issues with KopyKate BIG Official - May affect other sites
topic.body:
I just found an issue that erases an already downloaded video to re-download it again. I was seeding the video of the Mosques shooting uploaded by a certain user, then tried to see the same video but uploaded by another user. As the latter was loading I closed the video page as I was merely interested in the comments it had but noticed that the first instance of the same video was gone as well, and both videos uploaded by those two users were being downloaded at the same time. As I can see both videos share the same hash so the site just over-wrote it. 

Videos should have a distinguishable filename to avoid this, or better, the site should check if the file exists before attempting to do anything; this could help to kickstart seeding of some videos by placing the video in the zite folder and then trying to watch the video on the zite.

Keep zeroing~

topic.title: Painlessly publish hundreds of content.json at the same time
topic.body:
I'm in the need of signing and publishing A LOT of content.json files whenever I update my zite [rexresearch.com mirror](/1D6QfsBSZHmYWbuCxKG5ya31BiTczoZiES) from the clearnet site. I've prepared scripts to enqueue all the changed content.json files for signing and then publishing but I feel this approach is bad as it takes TONS of time for the publishing part, and it doesn't always play well when zeronet is running simultaneously.

Is there a way for officially enqueue the signing and publishing of more than one content.json file at a time?
**@gitcenter**

1553123831_191jbK3GNmVritcMymKkFuxyYFXxq.body:
> [newbeee](#comment_1_15FSWMpFYx3qtqhVpexSiM7jdHc1QYNtiz): one idea would be to have a "data-files" folder on same level inside ZN-master folder as "data" and all big optional files over 1MB inside. [...]

Sounds like a good approach, only take one thing into account: The handling of the file should be treated like a non-mutable object wich will exist as long as there's at least one reference to it in any zite, like, how objects are handled in garbage-collector using programming languages. Say you have the same video or picture being used (referenced) in ZeroMe, ZeroUp and KopyKate for example, you may delete the file 'logically' from any of those sites but the file on-disk won't be ever touched unless the three of those sites actually delete it, so there's no lingering references to a file and that file becomes truly disposable.

Keep Zeroing~

1553888479_1GDzVsFoYamHqWcYBcuvVWFCAt3Y5.body: I think linux filesystems are more resilient but lack info to prove it. Zeronet should be fine on any of those (windows or linux) as long as the system doesn't crash for something. Do regular backups though.

> [styromaniac](#comment_653_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): Just don't use any unstable file systems. For instance, btrfs was still not ready for serious tasks since it wasn't finished. Whatever Microsoft or Linux default on and recommend will be fine. You should prefer a journaled file system though. NTFS had to be defragmented without journaling.

Just to add, my main FS has been btrfs since a real while ago, more than 2 years now I think. It's pretty solid but it's almost a requisite to be aware of its many quirks and features. Snapshots did save me from some zeronet corruption (since SIGTERM isn't being handled properly) and many more times has helped me bear the not-always-stable ArchLinux updates. It's not meant for backing databases or virtual machines tho but I've found it pretty stable in my experience. Don't recommend if you don't plan to keep an eye over your filesystem.

I'm here, so yeah the zite is not publishing properly, when trying to Sign and Publish it just timeouts, the zite size as of now is 6.7G though html files went down to 194M and I have content.json to make everything that isn't an HTML file to be optional, but the site always fails to publish.

> [krixano](#comment_733_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu): I think you need to increase the "Size Limit" in the sidebar. I'm not sure though - I usually don't make zites this big without using optional files.

I did, it wouldn't sign if I weren't to set the limit over 200MB since I was making all html files (lots of them) as non-optional. Had to do it for it to even sign in my end, but it won't work for proxies like that.

I have a question, I already made everything in the zite to be optional but 0net.io still won't update so I wonder. Maybe the issue is not on how big the size of the core zite is but the content.json file (which is like 4.2MB as of now). Is there a way to split the file hashes among other content.json files? like, having a content.json file for each folder which contains hashes for only the files in said folder and any subdirectory in it would have a respective content.json.

Is it possible to do this?

> [caryoscelus](#comment_115_13oRBYqNeUr6Tvgt4KkAT9FT4XRiKFBjnE): That's how typical data/users directory operate, i think it should work with regular directories as well. It's called an "include" or something like that: you need to reference child content.json from parent one

I'm testing that in another site, so I added one folder to the zite root folder and modified /content.json to ignore the whole folder, say 'subdir'. Then in 'content.json' I added the include for 'subdir/content.json'. When signing it does skip all files under 'subdir' but I'd expect it to actually sign them and put in under 'subdir/content.json' instead, which it isn't doing.

What I want is a way to make every folder have a content.json file that contains said folder files' hashes so no content.json is huge enough to make publishing fail or a zeronet instance to stall if the user/zite tries accessing a broken link or a not yet downloaded file. Any ideas if that's actually achievable? or do I have to manually make all hashes for non root content.json file?

Keep Zeroing~

Update: I've been playing under a new zite about using a content.json file per folder, at first it seemed impossible since I wasn't understanding what was required here and there; so far the new zite is working ok, across MANY content.json files I have included all files of the site and the main zite content.json is tiny as of now (moved all files under a data/ folder) but have to double check it again, it's being syncing on my raspberry pi zeronet instance good enough but there are a couple things yet to check before attempting modifications on the main zite.

- As of now, I must check how to make a seamless redirect from the top index.html file to data/index.html file so I can keep everything contained under data/ dir, which allows for a tiny top content.json file and,
- have to modify already downloaded files on the raspberry pi instance and see if it raises an error or at least denies access (to check if I can trust this many content.json approach still stops keeps integrity of the files).

Things are finally looking good, I'm eager to improve the mirroring script to deal with the deployment of all those content.json files and call it a day. On the other side, having to sign all those content files do take a while but it won't matter when everything's set up.

Keep zeroing~

Finally!!, the approach of using one content.json for each top folder did work, the top content.json is now only 148K or so and was properly synced by [0net.io](https://0net.io/1D6QfsBSZHmYWbuCxKG5ya31BiTczoZiES). So far it works, the proxy won't download more content beyond the 10M size limit and the zite requires like 200M for the html files (I made everything that isn't an HTML file to be optional) so it would require the owner of the proxy to raise the limit.

I have to make sure that files verification sums are enforced but with this approach the zite mirroring will be streamlined. Thanks for all the info/help, specially you @ssdifnskdjfnsdjk .
 
Keep zeroing~

> [ssdifnskdjfnsdjk](#comment_802_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS): ... ZeroHello shows Rex Research was "stuck" (was active downloading, but no countdown) at 17099 remaining file parts to be downloaded. 

I think I found the problem at hand, so I have to publish every single content.json file when I sign them :/, I was oblivion to that, just tested it on my rpi that wasn't syncing to the latest version of some pdf files then did "Sign and Publish" the pdf/content.json and it worked like a charm. I'll tweak my signing script to also publish all files at the end, hopefully it gives me a break. Jeez!

After that I'll have to improve all my scripts to only work over the changed files so I don't have to wait hours nor publish 7MB worth of content.json files.

@ssdifnskdjfnsdjk: thanks for the constant feedback.

Keep Zeroing~

> [alexandre9099](#comment_3_16jR7jLoJPHcGJV9tE1uSugPNMNDvS4zXA): I see, but in case of a "big" website there would be a server at least seeding (acting as a peer, i don't understand much on how zeronet works yet) , so it would never go offline, unless that server went down (same as in clearnet )

There are no servers in here as in the sense of the clearnet, users of zeronet host copies of the site and when they are of online the site is served by them as well, if anyone puts a dedicated machine to act as a peer then that gives the site a peer that won't likely become offline. That's how it works, if a big site has many peers it's likely that those are among different time zones, so when a handful of those are offline some others may be online and it keeps online overall.

1562456132_1JcHMiQxXHX9q3ZK2LF9rZjvg3MUt.body:
reliability: Zeronet is a bit fragile with it's databases, I do some odd signing and publishing from scripts and I keep my backups because everything can go wrong.

local peers finding: I don't know of the algos to make it happen but some have mentioned the use-case of mesh networks in case SHTF.

global categorization: if all files (or at least big files) will be backed by IPFS then keeping a list of tags about every file would help tell apart stuff, and sites may use those tags to filter content. Since IPFS files are unique then they won't change and if some are NSFW then some sites would disallow the upload of such or users could use custom filters to block or hide such content. It could help ease your average browsing or enter a family-safe environment for browsing zeronet when kids or conventional people are to use it/are nearby when browsing. This doesn't have to be done at a close-to-core level of IPZN, a site that keeps such information would be enough and other could just query it.

That's it for now.

1567815493_14vGy5BMcRS26xrfaVZfcTuVm8XTa.body:
Well, I've never attempted against myself in a really endangering way, I've always been wary of just laying there half-alive half-dead feeling pain all along until I bleed my life away or someone finds me and the medical services try to keep me alive, either way will hurt and will take a while as well. That and also that I feel like ending it all is like giving up and I consider myself too pride for such thing, think of me as a more humble version of Vegeta. As for your beloved one, it's gone, that's true and we don't know why, or how is it doing now (afterlife assumptions) but you're still here, you don't know what's waiting for you if you end it all, I wouldn't say it'd be worse than how your life is as of now but it could be the same, which is bad as well. Now, I've actually felt like a utterly powerless excuse of a person, dragged by society with many many eyes looking down on me, dissapointed. At those times I just moved out of the scene when able, that is locking in my room, skipping all social activities (wasn't ever a fan of socializing...) and never taking the initiative for doing things even if I liked them. I bet it was just my fear from death and pain what kept me alive at those times but now I for sure know something. I've noticed that, what was keeping me down was my own lack of sheer will to start doing things, not saying that you just need to go to the park and breathe and stuff, instead just *do*, do what you must to stay alive and move on but this alone won't make anyone move one leg after another, you also need a *reason*, may it be a dream, a goal or just a short-term checkmark just find something and stick to it (wouldn't recommend religions, anything can happen with those). To be honest, the you of now may be just taking everything bad out of your life and self-inducing a really lame overall feeling, but probably months/years later you could really make a laugh out of the current you.

If the wind is freezing cold and the sun won't shine for you then grab some wood, grab some fur and somehow make it through the winter, you'll find reasons to think different soon enough. Best regards and good luck.

1570416195_12tcdM86TcZQeHEsSea3kTdTiExBK.body: There's Artix (arch linux - systemd) too, it has flavors for openrc and runit.

> [satoxyn1](#comment_114_1LGApmQZPN49nawg4HQQgf8ToVUPxGe2Zq): Systemd is the best what has happened with Linux in last 10 years. I'm absolutely serious. [...]

For a developer for many distros it may make your life easier, but for the end user it's a huge monster that controls everything and one can't really make a picture of where it begins and where it ends. Linux users are used to UNIX philosophy of make one thing properly. Also, it isn't as easy to customize for the end user and everything depends on it too. For example, I can disable and mask some services easily but can't really turn logging off, and afaik you still would have to keep some code for handling different distros unless all systemd distros just decided to do their stuff the same way, which could be done with other init systems as well. I'm using runit and it's lovely in terms of speed, maintenability and ease of use. There are few scripts for it in the repos so far but making my own isn't hard at all.

Now, let's be fair, I don't think I could run big time daemons with all the fancy stuff like isolation and cpu usage limit with it, but it does the job for me the average linux power user quite well.

1572864835_14g2gXnsZdEPShFJkGdh5W3eGXmKz.body: If the zeronet instance will be accessed only from the AP network, then you can just set it as a DNS static name so everyone who connects to that AP will get the resolve of zeronet.lan to the pi (if they get an IP with dhcp), also, the firewall thing can be done with iptables or nftables as well. I think one of those is better than ufw but I don't remember why. Finally, running a zeronet instance and powering two wifi dongles isn't too much of a power hog for the pi? unless you power the wifi adapters externally I think it may be a bit unstable.

Mind that not all usb 2.0 dongles are fully complaint with the USB 2.0 specification in terms of power draw, some may have spikes for really brief periods but that's enough to power reset my rpi 1 for example. Also, zeronet isn't really power demanding based on what it should be doing (that is an http server of sorts) but it relies on A LOT of encryption for everything and that's hardware intensive. If you only keep it for serving one or two sites then it's alright, also, there's the possibility to underclock a pi. rpi 1 stock clock is 700MHz but I run mine at 400MHz ( I think ) it's mainly for keeping its temps always low.

1572972136_17AMQVbBa12XB3xFWKDnP2dCEx92T.body:
remove all files from the content.json files and signed, open your zite and raise the size limit from 10MB to what you consider a good amount, then re-include files and try signing again. That's what I did for my +6GB zite ( tho only about 300MB are non-optional).

When someone downloads your zite it will ask for raising the limit but if the user agrees it will download everything.
Can I see your content.json? or what's your zite's link? My site does have all non-html files as optional but if I put a +10MB sized file as non-optional it doesn't complain at all.
The zite works properly but it says 20MB.zip was not found, does that file really exist in your zite folder?

Found out the issue, but not a solution. It seems that zeronet is configured by default to not download any file with a size bigger than 10MB (this doesn't apply for optional files), that's why your 20MB.zip file never got to download. I just started my zeronet client with --file_size_limit  30 and it's downloading your file. I tested it with another device running 0net in my LAN and it worked after raising the limit, so you now know what's the issue but not how to solve it seamlessly.

If your files bigger than 10MB are meant for archiving you should split them into chunks smaller than 10MB, if your files are instead media files then make your html pages embed them, that will make the browser fetch those files as they are needed for rendering the page. For example, my zite only includes html files but it doesn't require the user to manually download optional files; when someone opens a page that references pictures (optional files) those pictures are downloaded automatically to render the page, if they click the link to a PDF file it gets downloaded (I haven't tried embedded pdf reading but I think it would work as well too)

If you want to test what I mean, check my [testing zite](/1P2zTdkVjnr9kLM9R5KSzjiQp1rtWkWzda/), there are two file, both are 12MB each and only the optional one will work for you unless you use the --file_size_limit switch

The zite looks nice and stylish but I have some suggestions for making it easier on users in the long ride. You see, there is/was a zite called antilibrary, it is now abandoned (apparently) but it was a project for keeping a big library of books here in zeronet. I think the author was facing issues on how to store all the books while allowing users to only get the ones they wanted up to an extent (more like, a couple books stored in chunks, you wanted one from it, you get the chunk). Now your zite. I don't know if you'll only ever keep 5 books at any given time, or if your zite will be growing by five books each week. If the former then I'd suggest not using the names of the books as their file names, but using generic filenames based on positions like book-0, book-1, etc... this would properly overwrite the past week 5 books and your zite won't likely be leaving the, by then, not referenced 5 books of the past week lingering in the users directory folder (as far as I know, it won't delete files in the zite folder that don't figure in the content.json).
Instead, if you want to form a bigger library week by week, then mind storing every week's books in their own folder per week, with their respective content.json file and an include referencing all those week's content files. This will ensure your content.json files won't grow too big over time, and I think it aids with organization :)

Good luck and thanks for the books.

1580575907_17FotRRc6msHBzM2jrs6tQCmpLaXi.body:
if you want to connect to a peer directly for let's say getting a zite updated from the local version of that peer or just reaching more connectivity with it, you can open a zite adding /?zeronet_peers=<address of your peers separated by comma>. You can see an example by pulling zeronet sidebar and clicking the **copy to clipboard** link. it will paste the current zite you are visiting and append a list of peers you are already connected to, then you can append the link of your desired peer to it and open that URL.

If you want steady communication back and forth I think you'll end needing to enable the bootstrap plugin.

I personally take my time to check for updates periodically and I like being present and aware when an update is about to be installed. That way I can start updates when I have enough free time to fix whatever goes wrong with it (and actually make snapshots of my zeronet folder so said update won't cripple my instance irreparably).

> [cexy](#comment_60_1Fjz1g7unEcMnTRy7nc9WUBZdA7eHkc7BL): @mg0 From what I know this i5 CPU I have is x64 not x86. Could you shortly explain why you say x86 CPU machine can not be spy free in x64 todays standard? [...]

x86 is the name of the cpu architecture that started with OLD 8086 cpus, then 80286, 80386, 80486, ... (hence x86). x64 is an abbreviation to x86_64 which means the x86 cpu architecture with support to 64bit operations and addresses. First x86 cpus supporting 64bit were the AMD Athlon64 family afaik, and it coined the AMD64 name for those 64bit able x86 cpus. Nowadays x64, x86_64 and AMD64 mean mostly the same to the average joe, but the point is that x64 is part of x86.

1589077573_191qyhaRxXEx1bdtG65iQvFddtXBj.body:
As styro mentioned, all files bigger than 10MB are by default denied to be included in a site's required files (it can be raised but it must be done on the user zeronet instance, so don't rely on it), for such big files you must make them optional files. The regex for the optional line isn't the most intuitive imo so a bit of trial and error is in order.

I think your optional line should be something like:
  `"optional": "data/users/.+/optional/"`
but, I think that's not the proper approach if you are handling user-owned content; I haven't worked with it myself but I've seen other sites instead ignore the data/users folder while including a single content.json with:
  `"include": "data/users/content.json"`

That content.json must have all the available users and their permissions (file size limits, etc..). It may or may not work well for your case. In any case, keep trying with the optional line.

> [fantoski](#comment_80_191qyhaRxXEx1bdtG65iQvFddtXBjgo6j3): BTW I tried your line and it's still not working but I'll try to find how to use ZN's regex in the doc.

If you can, please get us the log when you try to sign your site, as it states which files are being required and which are listed as optional.

> [fantoski](#comment_81_191qyhaRxXEx1bdtG65iQvFddtXBjgo6j3): Sorry if it's long:  [...]

Well, the issue is that it isn't taking any file as optional. You see, when a file is made optional it is listed as:
    `[OPTIONAL] name of the file`
but all those files are just listed without it, so they are included as required files. You must fix your optional line, my previous suggestion assumed your optional content was under data/users/.*/ but in this case it seems that
    `"optional": "optional/.*"`
should suffice your case. Please try that one and tell us how it goes.

1603504012_1CNbp1ekMfWRzS6QeEYMoD9UxHgmn.body: you just have to enter a zite to download it, and then pull the zeronet sidebar at said site and enable "HELP DISTRIBUTE ADDED OPTIONAL FILES" and then push the button "Download previous files". It should start downloading all files of said site but it doesn't always finish at the first (and if your network is slow it won't for sure) so you might have to press that last button every now and then but that's it.

You can configure your raspberry pi's zeronet config file for including auto download of optional files and big files (no bigger than a set file size), and you'd have to add more addresses to which your raspberry pi will have zeronet listening for ui connections, so you can connect to your zeronet instance in your pi using the browser in your laptop or desktop or phone or smart tv ... Mind not to leave open ports to the internet for security purposes, better set up a a firewall.
Or you could set up an ssh tunnel for that.

1604050476_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2.body:
I'd like to know if there could ever be a collision on the hashing for the block filenames (given that it is truncated to 32 bytes). Regarding the symlinks approach, I admire the genius of taking advantage of ext filesytem family for storing small symlinks in inodes but I think portability is of better service for zeronet as a whole so now I want feedback on this idea:

I have to read about details of berkeley DBs but what if each site folder instead contained a single files.db folder storing the pairs of filename <-> block hash that the symlink approach tries to solve? if there are no big issues with the DB format (or maybe good ol' sqlite could suffice) it would solve the problem in a portable way and even it could be used with indexes over the block hashes (they are of fixed length too) so the refcount keeping for each content block under __blockspace__ becomes less indispensable as it would be reasonably fast to query a couple hundred indexed db's in case a refcount isn't reliable, and the sheer amount of files in the zeronet folder tree would be quite smaller (if it's of any service).

Another suggestion is for implementing a wayback machine sort of functionality; since the content will be deduplicated automatically almost all use cases will see a dramatical speed up and space usage reduction and everything that a given site's folder will do is just have all its files scattered linking to the correct content blocks but storing pretty much nothing on themselves, so it's quite easy to just zip/tar that folder structure with a timestamp and automatically it becomes a snapshot of the zite (would also work with the berkeley/sqlite db approach I suggested above but there would be no need for zipping, only copy-rename)

Finally, I have a question for big files support, I've noticed that everynow and then zeronet seems to treat piecemap.msgpack files as either content or piecemaps (that is, sometimes it counts it as files part of the site, other times as meta files solely there for keeping track of a big file download progress), will there still be need for such files? can it be solved with just a db file for big files pieces (piecemaps.db maybe?) per site?

1608035871_185GTTshXdJKtwsb8pWjobkFwufjR.body:
Not tested but that's your task now ;)
[Paste at NullPaste](/1MgHVPCE1ve6QfKrgsqCURzRj72HrRWioz/?1LbP2cNA6NkvuFJvs7McUmv9qGjkNqVkTa_0)

```
## Upgrade and install TOR
sudo apt update
sudo apt upgrade
sudo apt install tor
sudo apt install proxychains ## Easier way of proxying apps through tor

## Edit TOR configuration
sudo sed -i 's/#\?CookieAuthentication.*/CookieAuthentication 1/' /etc/tor/torrc
sudo sed -i 's/#\?ControlPort.*/ControlPort 9051/' /etc/tor/torrc

## Download ZeroNet bundle
proxychains -q wget -O ZeroNet-py3.linux64.tar.gz 'https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet-linux/archive/dist-linux64/ZeroNet-py3.linux.tar.gz'
tar -xvpz -f ZeroNet-py3.linux64.tar.gz

## Add user to TOR group
sudo usermod -a -G debian-tor `id -un`

## Log-in again to apply group changes
# Exit desktop or terminal session and enter again
# no real need to fully restart. Terminating all
# user started programs could do for now.
echo "About to kill all user started programs to apply TOR group changes."
echo "Close any important stuff you don't want to lose, or say N and restart later."
echo -n "Kill all user programs? [y/N]: "
read ANS
if test $ANS == 'y' -o $ANS == 'Y'; then
	killall -u
fi

## Disconnect from the internet
# Not really needed, zeronet config can be edited prior to running it.
# Config can be at /etc/zeronet.conf, if the bundle has its own file
# elsewhere then change this script to reflect that.

echo -e "\
tor_controller = 127.0.0.1:9051\n\
tor_proxy = 127.0.0.1:9050\n\
tor = always\n\
trackers_proxy = tor\n\
" | sudo tee -a /etc/zeronet.conf # editing /etc/zeronet.conf requires root powers

cd ZeroNet-linux-dist-linux64/
./ZeroNet.sh

```
